title: LIDL: LLM Integration Defect Localization via Knowledge Graph-Enhanced Multi-Agent Analysis
data:
G Tan, Z He, M Li, P Chen, J Shi, Z Sun, T Zhang- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
LLM-integrated software, which embeds or interacts with large language models 
(LLMs) as functional components, exhibits probabilistic and context-dependent 
behaviors that fundamentally differ from those of traditional software. This shift 
introduces a new category of integration defects that arise not only from code errors 
but also from misaligned interactions among LLM-specific artifacts, including 
prompts, API calls, configurations, and model outputs. However, existing defect

title: OODEval: Evaluating Large Language Models on Object-Oriented Design
data:
B Xiao, Y Dong, Y Tang, M Zhang, Y Zhou, C Ma, Y Liu- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have driven extensive 
evaluations in software engineering. however, most prior work concentrates on code-
level tasks, leaving software design capabilities underexplored. To fill this gap, we 
conduct a comprehensive empirical study evaluating 29 LLMs on object-oriented 
design (OOD) tasks. Owing to the lack of standardized benchmarks and metrics, we 
introduce OODEval, a manually constructed benchmark comprising 50 OOD tasks of
Cites: Assessing and Advancing Benchmarks for Evaluating Large
author: Xin ZHOU

title: Foundation Models in Software Engineering: A Taxonomy, Systematic Review, and In-Depth Analysis of Testing Support
data:
S Banitaan, M Daoud, H Alquran, M Akour- Information, 2026
Foundation models are increasingly influencing software engineering research and 
practice, yet their adoption across the software development life cycle remains 
uneven and insufficiently characterized. This paper presents a systematic review of 
224 recent studies investigating the application of foundation models to software 
engineering tasks. We introduce a two-dimensional taxonomy that systematically 
links software engineering life cycle phases with the foundation model capabilities
Cites: Large language model for vulnerability detection: Emerging results

title: Lightweight Yet Secure: Secure Scripting Language Generation via Lightweight LLMs
data:
K Zhang, Z Chen, X Feng, D Fang, Y Zheng, Z Li, L Sun- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
The security of scripting languages such as PowerShell is critical given their powerful 
automation and administration capabilities, often exercised with elevated privileges. 
Today, securing these languages still demands substantial human effort to craft and 
enforce rules, imposing heavy burdens on typical administrators and creating critical

title: Large Language Model Approaches to Educational Video Generation Using Manim
data:
RS Rammuni Silva, A Lotfi, IK Ihianle- UK Workshop on, 2025
The automated generation of educational videos based on Large Language Models 
(LLMs) holds promising potential to enhance pedagogy. This study investigates the 
use of compact LLMs with fewer than 10 billion parameters, utilising Parameter-
Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) techniques to generate Manim Python code that 
produces images and videos for educational visualisations from natural language 
narratives. This approach is highly resource-efficient compared to diffusion-based
Cites: Exploring Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning Techniques for Code

title: PenForge: On-the-Fly Expert Agent Construction for Automated Penetration Testing
data:
H Huang, J Shi, J Chen, T Zhang, Y Li, C Yang, EL Ouh- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
Penetration testing is essential for identifying vulnerabilities in web applications 
before real adversaries can exploit them. Recent work has explored automating this 
process with Large Language Model (LLM)-powered agents, but existing 
approaches either rely on a single generic agent that struggles in complex scenarios 
or narrowly specialized agents that cannot adapt to diverse vulnerability types. We 
therefore introduce PenForge, a framework that dynamically constructs expert agents
Cites: Back to the Basics: Rethinking Issue-Commit Linking with LLM

title: How Secure is Secure Code Generation? Adversarial Prompts Put LLM Defenses to the Test
data:
M Tessa, IE Olatunji, A War, J Klein, TF Bissyand- arXiv preprint arXiv:2601.07084, 2026
Recent secure code generation methods, using vulnerability-aware fine-tuning, 
prefix-tuning, and prompt optimization, claim to prevent LLMs from producing 
insecure code. However, their robustness under adversarial conditions remains 
untested, and current evaluations decouple security from functionality, potentially 
inflating reported gains. We present the first systematic adversarial audit of state-of-
the-art secure code generation methods (SVEN, SafeCoder, PromSec). We subject
Cites: Stealthy backdoor attack for code models

data:

title: Forward Symbolic Execution for Trustworthy Automation of Binary Code Verification
data:
A Lindner, K Palmskog, S Constable, M Dam- International Conference on, 2026
Control flow in unstructured programs can be complex and dynamic, which makes 
static analysis difficult. Yet, automated reasoning about unstructured control flow is 
important when certifying properties of binary (machine) code in trustworthy systems, 
eg, cryptographic routines. We present a theory of forward symbolic execution for 
unstructured programs suitable for use in theorem provers that enables automated 
verification of both functional and non-functional program properties. The theory's
Cites: Modeling out-of-order processors for WCET analysis

data:

education, provide detailed insights into student knowledge. However, training large 
language models (LLMs) to simulate and predict possible student errors in their

in student responses. In this work, we present KASER (Knowledge-Aligned Student

a wide spectrum of techniques. However, a fundamental challenge persists: highly
